verses.text: After the uproar had ended, Paul summoned the disciples, encouraged them, said farewell, and departed to go to Macedonia.
verses.comment: Paul's pattern of strengthening and encouraging believers before departing shows pastoral care and concern for the unity of the Church.

verses.text: When he had traveled through those regions and had given the believers much encouragement, he came to Greece.
verses.comment: Paul’s journey through Macedonia and Greece reflects the early Christian mission spreading through varied communities, rooted in apostolic succession.

verses.text: He spent three months there. When a plot was made against him by the Jews as he was about to sail for Syria, he decided to return through Macedonia.
verses.comment: This change of plans underlines God’s providential guidance over the apostles amid opposition and persecution.

verses.text: He was accompanied by Sopater of Berea, the son of Pyrrhus; by Aristarchus and Secundus of Thessalonica; Gaius of Derbe; Timothy; and Tychicus and Trophimus from Asia.
verses.comment: The list of Paul’s companions, representing various local churches, highlights the unity and diversity founded on the apostles.

verses.text: These men went on ahead and waited for us at Troas.
verses.comment: The narrative shifts to the first person here ('us'), indicating that Luke, the author, was an eyewitness present for these events.

verses.text: But we sailed from Philippi after the days of Unleavened Bread, and in five days we joined them at Troas, where we stayed seven days.
verses.comment: Reference to 'the days of Unleavened Bread' shows early Christian respect for Jewish feasts, hinting at continuity of tradition.

verses.text: On the first day of the week, we gathered together to break bread. Paul spoke to them, and because he intended to depart the next day, he prolonged his speech until midnight.
verses.comment: Breaking bread on the first day prefigures the Christian practice of Sunday worship centered around the Eucharist, showing liturgical continuity from the apostles.

verses.text: There were many lamps in the upstairs room where we were assembled.
verses.comment: Details such as the many lamps underscore the realism and eyewitness nature of the narrative.

verses.text: And a young man named Eutychus, sitting at the window, was overcome by deep sleep as Paul spoke for a long time. Overcome by sleep, he fell down from the third story and was picked up dead.
verses.comment: Eutychus's fall and apparent death highlight the miraculous power working through the apostles, pointing to a visible, supernatural Church.

verses.text: But Paul went down, threw himself on him, embraced him, and said, 'Do not be alarmed, for his life is in him.'
verses.comment: Paul’s action recalls Old Testament prophets raising the dead (e.g., Elijah, Elisha), signifying the continuation of prophetic authority through apostolic ministry.

verses.text: After going back upstairs, breaking bread, and eating, Paul conversed with them for a long time, until daybreak, and so he departed.
verses.comment: The repetition of 'breaking bread' emphasizes the centrality of the Eucharistic meal in early Christian worship, not just a common meal.

verses.text: They took the young man home alive, and were greatly comforted.
verses.comment: The restoration of Eutychus testifies to apostolic authority and the encouragement brought to the gathered believers.

verses.text: But we went ahead to the ship and set sail for Assos, intending to take Paul aboard there. He had arranged this since he intended to go there on foot.
verses.comment: Paul’s personal journey on foot demonstrates his humility and perhaps desire for solitary prayer or reflection.

verses.text: When he met us at Assos, we took him aboard and went to Mitylene.
verses.comment: This detailed travel narrative reflects Luke’s eyewitness accuracy and highlights the genuine nature of these events.

verses.text: We sailed from there, and the following day arrived opposite Chios; the next day we touched at Samos; and the day after that, we came to Miletus.
verses.comment: The sequence of travel points to historical geography and careful preservation of the Church’s origins.

verses.text: For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus so that he would not spend time in Asia, because he was hurrying to be in Jerusalem, if possible, on the day of Pentecost.
verses.comment: Paul’s goal to reach Jerusalem for Pentecost places value on Church feasts, rooted in God’s salvation history.

verses.text: From Miletus he sent word to Ephesus and called for the elders of the church to come to him.
verses.comment: Paul’s summons of the elders (presbyters) demonstrates early episcopal structure and shared leadership in the Christian community.

verses.text: When they arrived, he said to them, 'You know how I lived among you the whole time from the first day I set foot in Asia,'
verses.comment: Paul appeals to his own conduct as a model of Christian and apostolic living, setting a pattern for elders overseeing the Church.

verses.text: 'serving the Lord with all humility, with tears, and with trials that came upon me through the plots of the Jews.'
verses.comment: Paul’s humble service mirrors Christ’s own self-giving for the Church (cf. Phil. 2:7-8).

verses.text: 'I did not shrink from declaring to you anything that was profitable, teaching you in public and from house to house,'
verses.comment: Paul was tireless in teaching both publicly and privately, reflecting the Church’s commitment to catechesis in all settings.

verses.text: 'testifying both to Jews and to Greeks about repentance toward God and faith in our Lord Jesus.'
verses.comment: Repentance and faith are universal requirements for salvation, emphasizing the unity of God’s plan for all nations.

verses.text: 'And now, behold, I am going to Jerusalem, compelled by the Spirit, not knowing what will happen to me there,'
verses.comment: Paul’s obedience to the Spirit’s leading foreshadows Christ’s own journey toward Jerusalem and self-sacrifice.

verses.text: 'except that the Holy Spirit testifies to me in every city that imprisonment and afflictions await me.'
verses.comment: The Spirit’s warning prepares Paul, just as Jesus foretold His own suffering (cf. Luke 18:31-33).

verses.text: 'But I do not account my life as of any value to myself, if only I may finish my course and the ministry which I received from the Lord Jesus, to testify to the good news of God’s grace.'
verses.comment: Paul’s self-sacrifice mirrors Christ’s total offering; true ministry is rooted in self-denial and love.

verses.text: 'Now I know that none of you among whom I have gone about proclaiming the kingdom will see my face again.'
verses.comment: Paul’s farewell echoes Jesus’ final discourses and underscores the solemnity of apostolic succession within the Church.

verses.text: 'Therefore I testify to you this day that I am innocent of the blood of all of you,'
verses.comment: Paul’s imagery alludes to Ezekiel the watchman, indicating the seriousness of teaching sound doctrine.

verses.text: 'for I did not shrink from declaring to you the entire counsel of God.'
verses.comment: Paul’s witness is full; the Church is founded on the entirety of divine revelation, not partial teachings.

verses.text: 'Pay careful attention to yourselves and to all the flock, over which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers, to shepherd the church of God which he obtained with his own blood.'
verses.comment: Paul exhorts the overseers (episkopoi, translated as bishops) to guard the flock. The reference to 'his own blood' affirms Christ's divinity and the Church’s special relationship to Christ through His sacrifice.

verses.text: 'I know that after my departure, savage wolves will come in among you, not sparing the flock.'
verses.comment: Protection from false teachers is through apostolic leadership and fidelity to sound doctrine, stressing visible unity.

verses.text: 'Even from among your own number men will arise, speaking twisted things, to draw away the disciples after them.'
verses.comment: Schisms and heresies were present from the beginning; faithfulness to apostolic teaching is necessary for true unity.

verses.text: 'Therefore be on the alert, remembering that for three years I did not cease night or day to admonish everyone with tears.'
verses.comment: Paul’s emotional investment and tireless vigilance demonstrate the pastoral heart called for in the leaders of the Church.

verses.text: 'And now I commend you to God and to the word of his grace, which is able to build you up and to give you an inheritance among all those who are sanctified.'
verses.comment: Sanctification is both individual and corporate, rooted in the grace transmitted through the community.

verses.text: 'I coveted no one’s silver or gold or clothing.'
verses.comment: Paul’s detachment from material goods imitates Christ’s poverty and points to apostolic integrity.

verses.text: 'You yourselves know that these hands of mine provided for my own needs and the needs of those who were with me.'
verses.comment: Paul’s self-support magnifies his service and lessens potential accusation, providing an example for church leaders.

verses.text: 'In all things I have shown you that by working hard in this way we must help the weak, and remember the words of the Lord Jesus, how he said, “It is more blessed to give than to receive.”'
verses.comment: The Church’s mission includes charity and selfless service, as taught and exemplified by the Lord Himself.

verses.text: When he had said these things, he knelt down and prayed with them all.
verses.comment: Paul’s kneeling for prayer with the elders shows the early Church’s posture of worship, humility, and dependence on God.

verses.text: There was much weeping among them all; they embraced Paul and kissed him,
verses.comment: The deep affection between Paul and the elders highlights the bonds formed in the Christian community and the spiritual fatherhood of the apostles.

verses.text: saddened most of all because he had said they would not see his face again. And they accompanied him to the ship.
verses.comment: The profound sorrow at this farewell evokes the emotional depth of the apostolic age and the sacrificial nature of ministry, anticipating the Church’s ongoing missionary call.
